prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
12CO (3-2) is optically thick almost everywhere, and the disk kinetic temperatures are in the range 10 - 50 K. We set here a goal of 0.3K rms, for 0.8" resolution and 0.2 km/s representative spectral resolution.
The chosen spectral resolution sample well the local line width (0.3-0.4 km/s). The total line width is <6 km/s.
The 0.8" is suitable to resolve the disk.

12CO (6-5) is optically thick almost everywhere, and must arise from a layer with kinetic temperatures 10 - 100 K. We set here a goal of 1K rms, for 0.8" resolution and 0.2 km/s representative spectral resolution.
The chosen spectral resolution sample well the local line width (0.3-0.4 km/s). The total line width is <6 km/s.
The overall disk size is about 10", but because of the Keplerian shear, the typical size in each velocity channel is 6"x2", so structure filtering will be small. Moreover, for the CO J=6-5 line, the outer regions will be cold, hence the actual source size is expected to be substantially smaller than the overall disk size of about 10". We thus consider missing spatial scales are not an issue for our goal.

The 13CO and C18O (3-2) transitions will be about 2 times less optically thick than the J=2-1 lines studies in Dartois et al 2003. These J=2-1 lines have brightness temperature in the range 0.5 to 10 K.
We thus set here a goal of 0.7K rms, for 0.8" resolution and 0.2 km/s representative spectral resolution.
The 0.8" is suitable to resolve the disk.

The 13CO and C18O (3-2) transitions will be 1.5 times thicker than the J=2-1 lines studies in Dartois et al 2003. These J=2-1 lines have brightness temperature in the range 0.5 to 10 K.
We set here a goal of 0.3K rms, for 0.8" resolution and 0.2 km/s representative spectral resolution, and thus expect S/N 3 to 5 times better than in Dartois et al 2003.
The 0.8" is suitable to resolve the disk. The overall disk size is about 10", but because of the Keplerian shear, the typical size in each velocity channel is 6"x2", so structure filtering will be small.

We use here the minimal angular resolution, around 0.55'', and set a goal of 0.7 K in brightness for 0.2 km/s resolution.
The overall disk size is about 10", but because of the Keplerian shear, the typical size in each velocity channel is 6"x2", so structure filtering will be small. Moreover, for the CO J=6-5 line, the outer regions will be cold, hence the actual source size is expected to be substantially smaller than the overall disk size of about 10". We thus consider missing spatial scales are not an issue for our goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high spatial resolution ALMA observations of CO emission lines from the transition disk around the source DM Tau. Our aim is to infer the temperature structure of the disk from a multi-line (6-5, 3-2 and 1-0 transitions), multi-isotopic ($^{12}$C$^{16}$O,$^{13}$C$^{16}$O and $^{12}$C$^{18}$O) study which traces gas at different spatial locations and hence physical conditions in the disk. The observational program will be accompanied by detailed thermochemical modeling that includes selective photodissociation of isotopic species to compute the gas temperature. Ancillary HD 1-0 line flux measurements will be used to constrain the gas mass of the disk. Comparisons between models and ALMA data will allow us to determine disk gas temperature structure, which is important in regulating the chemical state of the disk and forms a key input to various disk evolutionary processes such as viscous accretion, photoevaporation and finally planet formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Ames Research Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
